author: b.hartnett
content:
I have a question about what validation should be applied to BALs. In the EIP under the state transition function section here https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7928#state-transition-function it suggests that we need to generate the BAL and check that it matches the balHash in addition to validating the supplied BAL in the block body. Is this rule only for non-finalized blocks? Or is this only for when validating via newPayload? Asking because it's possible to receive non-finalized blocks when syncing for example.

If a block header is considered finalized then I assume we don't need to generate the BAL, all we need to do is check the provided BAL in the block matches the balHash? 

Also if a block header is not finalized do we always need to apply the full validation (BAL generation included)? If so then clients can't simply apply the BAL state diff without executing the block in this case. This might effect the performance of snap sync near the head. Also if there is a period of non-finalization then there is an even larger range of blocks where this applies.

author: garyrong
content:
My stance is that we should keep BALs visible at the EL, but there is no need to integrate them into the block body. They can be passed alongside the payload through the engine API, similar to how requests work. BALs are not essential for block execution, instead they serve as an acceleration structure.

Separating BALs from the block body provides several advantages:

1. Decoupling BALs from block bodies

Message `BlockBodies (0x06)` no longer needs to include BAL data, which is non-trivial in response size.

2. Independent retrieval over devp2p

We can introduce `GetBlockLevelAccessList (0x12)` and `BlockLevelAccessList (0x13)` to the ETH protocol, allowing BALs to be fetched directly from the local database without touching block bodies at all. To be fair, this remains possible even if BALs were embedded in the body.

3. Independent retention policy

BALs can adopt a different retention strategy from bodies and receipts. A node that only cares about maintaining a live Ethereum state may keep just the last 128 bodies/receipts for handling mini reorgs and throw all others away. However, BALs are different from this perspective. Keeping roughly the last two weeks of BALs can benefit the robustness of snap sync. As I mentioned here https://github.com/ethereum/pm/issues/1822#issuecomment-3631844801

4. Optional for full-history nodes

Nodes that retain the entire historical chain (all headers and all block bodies back to genesis) do not strictly require receipts or BALs. These nodes are crucial for supporting users who need to perform a full sync from genesis or from any historical point for purposes such as (a) fully trustless chain verification, or (b) reconstructing historical state for archive nodes and so on.

Such full-history nodes can continue to be operated by the EF or other advanced users even after dynamic chain pruning is introduced. By omitting BALs, these nodes can significantly reduce their overall storage footprint.

author: nero_eth
content:
Small update to the EIP:
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/10895

It's clarifying that the system contract caller, `SYSTEM_ADDRESS` (`0xfffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffffe`, MUST NOT be included in the BAL unless it experiences a state access itself.

Clients should all fine and are handling this correctly already.
